content:
• Friday, December 27, 2013

  • After Hour Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers: VVUS +1.5%. SSYS +1.4%. CME +1.4%. SQNM +1.3%. CLDX +0.8%.
    • Top losers: MACK -1.8%. GT -1.2%. TWTR -1.1%. GOGO -0.8%. EXXI -0.8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:50 PM | 6 Comments
  • PTE

    Majesco Entertainment +10.2% AH, Yair Goldfinger discloses 7.2% stake

    • ICQ founder Yair Goldfinger discloses a 7.2% (3.33M share) stake in Majesco Entertainment (COOL). (SC 13G)
    • Shares +10.2% AH
     
     
     
     
    | 4:53 PM | 3 Comments

  • Weekly ETF Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: GDXJ +4.92%. REMX +4.11%. SIVR +3.61%. GDX +3.51%. SLV +3.49%.
    • Losers: VXX -5.87%. GAZ -4.80%. UNG -2.80%. VNM -2.47%. TLT -2.34%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:23 PM | 1 Comment
  • VALE

    Vale raises $150M by selling stakes in logistics, chemicals companies

    • Vale (VALE +3.1%) has sold its 31.3% stake in Brazilian logistics firm Logistica Intermodal for $98M through an auction on the Sao Paulo exchange, and its 44.25% stake is phosphoric acid producer Fosbrazil to Israel Chemicals for $52M.
    • The asset sales are part of the mining giant's efforts to shed non-core assets, and to focus on its core iron ore, nickel, coal, copper, and fertilizer businesses. Vale has sold $6B worth of non-core assets in 2013.
    • Previous: Vale considers selling coal, fertilizer stakes to strategic partners
     
     
     
     
    | 2:36 PM | 4 Comments
  • CRZO

    Carrizo Oil & Gas gets bullish initiation at Iberia

    • Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO +3%) is trading notably higher on the session.
    • Helping the cause is Iberia Capital, where analysts have initiated coverage at Outperform.
    • Price target is $55, representing upside of +26% from Thursday's close.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:22 PM
  • REE

    Rare earth miners take off

    • Rare earth miners Rare Element Resources (REE +12.9%), Avalon Rare Metals (AVL +3.7%), and Quest Rare Minerals (QRM +11.7%) have joined Molycorp (previous) in rallying sharply. Equity markets have doled out plenty of punishment to the group this year.
    • SA contributor Hawkinvest has provided a bullish write-up on Molycorp, arguing a short-covering rally could take place in early 2014.
    • The Rare Earth/Strategic Metals ETF (REMX +0.7%) remains down 32% YTD.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:13 PM | 7 Comments
  • NFLX

    U.S. Web momentum plays take a breather, Chinese peers don't

    • With high-flying Twitter (downgraded by Macquarie) leading the way, several Internet momentum plays that have delivered big 2013 gains are seeing some year-end profit-taking.
    • In addition to Twitter, notable decliners include Netflix (NFLX -2.8%), Pandora (P -3.6%), Trulia (TRLA -2.7%), Zillow (Z -2.4%), and Groupon (GRPN -1.9%).
    • On the other hand, many Chinese Internet names are adding to this year's gains. In addition to Baidu (buying Perfect World's e-book unit) and Ctrip (received a bullish T.H. Capital note), gainers include Sina (SINA +4.9%), Dangdang (DANG +4.8%), YY (YY +4%), 58.com (WUBA +3%), and NetEase (NTES +3.4%). An overnight Shanghai rally is likely helping.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:54 PM | 1 Comment
  • BIDU

    Baidu acquiring Perfect World online literature unit for $31.5M

    • Making good on a November Marbridge Consulting report, Baidu (BIDU +4.1%) has reached a deal to acquire Perfect World's (PWRD +1.8%) Huanxiang Zongheng online literature business (provides Chinese e-books, digital comics, and animations) for RMB191.5M ($31.5M). (PR)
    • Marbridge previously noted Zongheng offers 100K+ e-book titles, receives 60M+ daily page views, and gets over 1/3 of its site traffic via mobile.
    • The purchase is the latest in a string of 2013 acquisitions by Baidu, as the Chinese search giant attempts to create a far-reaching empire of Web/mobile content and services. Prior acquisitions: PPS, 91 Wireless, Nuomi.
    • Perfect World says the deal will allow it to focus on its core online gaming business. The company has been investing heavily in both developing new games and promoting existing ones.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:21 PM

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Top 10 Gainers: WPCS +79%. NETE +27%. AMRS +22%. ICLD +20%. ANIP +19%. FREE +17%. MVIS +16%. CTCH +16%. OTC:PGRX +15%. MCP +13%.
    • Top 10 Losers: IFON -17%. CLWT -13%. EDN -13%. LUNA -10%. MNDL -9%. STXS -8%. TNXP -8%. MBIS -8%. CAMT -7%. NCQ -7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:46 PM
  • CTRP

    Ctrip rallies, Qunar slumps following T.H. Capital note

    • T.H. Capital's Tian Hou believes cumulative downloads of Ctrip's (CTRP +3.2%) Android app (as of Monday) are up 16.3% since Nov. 19, thanks in part to a mobile-only hotel discount promotion covering eight major Chinese cities.
    • Rivals Qunar (QUNR -2.7%) and eLong (LONG +0.4%) are respectively estimated to have seen 11% and 14% cumulative Android app download growth over this time.
    • Hou also notes Ctrip's iOS app was ranked #3 on the Chinese App Store's travel app download list, trailing only a train ticket app and a taxi app.
    • Ctrip already had strong mobile exposure going into Q4: The company mentioned in its Q3 report mobile had grown to account for 30% of its hotel bookings (up from 20% in Q2), and 15% of its air ticket bookings.
    • Shares are up 130% YTD on what has been a very good year for Chinese Internet names.
    • Previous: Ctrip invests in, strikes partnership with online car rental firm
     
     
     
     
    | 12:41 PM
  • CUDA

    Barracuda Networks climbs 20% on positive CNBC mention

    • Barracuda Networks (CUDA +19.9%) shares climb after BMO's Joel Fishbein lauds the name on CNBC, saying Barracuda possesses "next generation technology ... that goes from protecting the endpoints to protecting the data no matter where it is and that's what corporations need to do such as Target."
     
     
     
     
    | 12:08 PM | 1 Comment
  • S

    Sprint jumps again amid growing T-Mobile hopes

    • Following today's big gains, Sprint (S +8.2%) is up 32% since the WSJ reported on Dec. 13 the carrier and parent SoftBank are weighing a 2014 bid for T-Mobile USA.
    • Short-covering could be contributing to Sprint's gains: 12.5% of the carrier's float was shorted as of Dec. 13.
    • Shares got a lift yesterday from a Wells Fargo note highlighting the value of Sprint's spectrum, and noting the potential of a T-Mobile deal to product major cost synergies.
    • More on Sprint/T-Mobile
     
     
     
     
    | 12:07 PM | 2 Comments
  • CYRN

    Commtouch Software spikes 19.4% on SA Pro article

    • Commtouch Software (CTCH +19.4%) shares spike after SA Pro's Igor Novgorodtsev makes the case (under embargo until 11:30am ET tomorrow) for why the company is an "obvious acquisition target" that could command a premium of up to 80%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:52 AM
  • OLED

    Universal Display slumps; Canaccord offers another skeptical take

    • Canaccord's Jonathan Dorsheimer is reiterating a Sell on Universal Display (OLED -2.1%) and predicting the OLED TV and bendable phone prototypes likely to be shown off at CES (runs from Jan. 7-10) won't translate into major commercial volumes.
    • Dorsheimer, who downgraded Universal to Sell on Oct. 1 (he cited checks pointing to Samsung/LG OLED material R&D programs), also highlights Sony and Panasonic's recent decision to call off an OLED TV JV.
    • Thanks to a mixture of strong green host/emitter material sales growth (fueled by high-end Samsung phones), margin/competition concerns, and patent news, Universal's shares have had plenty of ups and downs in 2013. With two trading days left in the the year, they're up 30% YTD.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:38 AM | 1 Comment
  • FCEL

    FuelCell Energy finishes 14.9MW project, shares rally

    • FuelCell Energy (FCEL +3.3%) has completed a 14.9MW fuel cell project in Bridgeport, CT for Dominion Resources. The project contains five fuel cell power plants, and is backed by a 15-year energy purchase agreement with a Connecticut electric utility. (PR)
    • News of the project comes ten days after FuelCell sold off in response to an FQ4 EPS miss.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:39 AM | 1 Comment
  • UAL

    Higher oil prices clip airline stocks

    • Airline stocks dip in early trading after a government report shows U.S. crude oil supplies stayed in a downward trend. Violence in the South Sudan has also been a recent factor in oil prices.
    • Besides the prospect for higher prices for aviation fuel, the airline sector was ripe to blow off a little steam after rallying before and after the merger of American Airlines and U.S. Airways, note analysts.
    • Decliners: United Continental (NASDAQ:UAL) -3.2%, Delta Air Lines (NYSE:DAL) -2.6%, Spirit Airlines (NASDAQ:SAVE) -2.4%, JetBlue (NASDAQ:JBLU) -1.5%, American Airlines (NASDAQ:AAL) -1.5%, Southwest Airlines (NYSE:LUV) -1.3%.
    • Related Oil ETFs: USO, OIL, UCO, SCO, DBO, DTO, CRUD, USL, DBE, UHN, RJN, DNO, SZO, OILZ, UWTI, OTC:DWTI, OLO, JJE-OLD, RGRE, ONG, OLEM, TWTI, UBN.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:19 AM
  • JKS

    JinkoSolar completes 80MW worth of solar projects, shares rally

    • JinkoSolar (JKS +4.1%) announces it has connected four Chinese solar projects providing 80MW of capacity between them to the national grid. The company has now cumulatively connected 213MW of projects to the grid. (PR)
    • Shares are now up 374% YTD on what has been a phenomenal year for most solar stocks.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:19 AM

  • How much lower can yen go?

    • Barring a big move higher in the next couple of sessions, the yen (FXY -0.2%) appears set to end 2013 pretty close to the year's low, the dollar buying more than ¥104 this morning vs. less than ¥80 in November 2012.
    • "We do not believe that the current pace of yen depreciation is sustainable," says JPMorgan's Junya Tanasa, expecting an unwind of the popular Nikkei long/yen short trade at some point in 2014.
    • For a contrary view, check out Kyle Bass, who contends the real move lower in the yen hasn't even begun yet. He's calling for dollar/yen rising all the way to ¥200 and - as we've all seen - once currencies get a head of steam going in a certain direction, no one can be sure of where the move will stop. ¥350? Why not?
    • Japan ETFs: DXJ, EWJ, FXY, YCS, JGBS, JGBD, DFJ, JYN, NKY, DBJP, EZJ, EWV, YCL, SCJ, JSC, ITF, JGBL, JPP, DXJS, JPNL, JGBT, JPNS, FJP, JGBB
     
     
     
     
    | 10:08 AM | 1 Comment
  • RGSE

    Cowen starts coverage on Real Goods Solar, shares +5.1% premarket

    • Cowen has started coverage on Real Goods Solar (RSOL) with an Outperform and $3.50 PT.
    • The solar panel installer has seen plenty of volatility this year. Shares are up 236% YTD, but down 64% from the high they saw in May after skyrocketing in response to a bullish SA column.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:17 AM

  • Premarket Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: WPCS +87%. FREE +16%. NEWL +9%. EGLE +6%. DRYS +6%. GNK +5%. RSOL +5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:10 AM
  • DCAR

    WPCS +72% after launch of Bitcoin trading platform

    • WPCS International (WPCS) is now higher by 72% in premarket action following last night's announcement of a launch of its Bitcoin [[BITCOIN]] trading platform. Bitcoin's latest price on Mt.Gox is $812.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:32 AM | 7 Comments
  • TWTR

    Twitter cut to Sell at Macquarie; off 2.8% premarket

    • The Twitter (NYSE:TWTR) rocket ship takes a pause in premarket trade, off 2.8% amid a downgrade to Sell from Macquarie's Ben Schachter.
    • "We expect this to be among the shortest downgrade note you’ve ever read, as nothing fundamentally has changed since our Neutral initiation on Dec. 11, except that shares have risen 40% ... [Twitter] has a bright future and many opportunities ahead. However, as a stock, we believe nothing has changed over the last 15 days to justify the rise in valuation."
    • He maintains his $46 price target.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:20 AM | 63 Comments
  • ANIP

    ANI Pharmaceuticals rallies after Teva deal

    • Shares of ANI Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:ANIP) trade 11% higher in premarket action.
    • Investors appear pleased with the company's acquisition of 31 generic products from Teva.
    • The deal "demonstrates ANI's commitment to diversify [the] marketed product portfolio and supplement internal product development efforts," the company says.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:19 AM
  • TKPHF

    Takeda ends development of late-stage diabetes drug

    • "The company has reached the conclusion that, on balance, the benefits of treating patients with fasiglifam do not outweigh the potential risks,” Takeda (OTCPK:TKPHF) says, ending development of its late-stage GPR40 agonist TAK-875.
    • The drug was tied to liver damage.
    • The company had hoped the treatment would help offset revenue lost to generic Actos, the diabetes drug which at one time accounted for more than a quarter of Takeda's top-line.
    • Shares fell 5%+ in Tokyo on the news.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:51 AM

  • Turkey tumbles another 5% as corruption crisis continues

    • The Istanbul National 100 Index is off nearly another 5% as Prime Minster Erdogan's cabinet shuffle - in which he replaced half of his team with arch-loyalists -  has failed to halt the opposition. TUR -7.7% premarket.
    • The weakening lira looks to be giving the euro (FXE) a bid across the board; it's ahead 1.1% vs. the greenback to $1.3842 - the highest level in more than 2 years. European stocks overall are doing fine, the Stoxx 50 up 1%.
    • Euro ETFs: FXE, EUO, ERO, DRR, EUFX, ULE, URR
     
     
     
     
    | 7:39 AM | 19 Comments
  • MBOT

    Stemcells files to raise $100M

    • Stemcells (STEM) has made a filing to raise $100M in stock, warrants and/or debt securities, saying that the registration statement will become effective "from time to time."
    • Stemcells plans to use the proceeds for general corporate purposes, including R&D, clinical trials and acquisitions.
    • Shares closed flat at $1.32 yesterday but rose 5.3% in AH trading. (S-3)
     
     
     
     
    | 7:01 AM | 3 Comments

  • Asian, EU stocks rise, U.S. futures down, Turkey hammered

    • Stocks in Asia and Europe mostly rise as investors in the latter region return to work following the Christmas break, although U.S. stock futures are slightly lower after decent gains yesterday.
    • Chinese shares lead the way with an increase of 1.4%, helped by money markets continuing to ease following a mini squeeze. The seven day repo is -24 bps at 5.09%.
    • However, Turkish equities again suffer badly from the corruption scandal engulfing the government, with the ISE 100 -4.1%.
    • Japan flat, Hong Kong +0.3% India +0.6%.
    • EU Stoxx 50 +1%, London +0.6%, Paris +1%, Frankfurt +0.8%, Milan +0.6%, Madrid +0.5%.
    • U.S. stock futures: Dow flat. S&P -0.1%. Nasdaq -0.05%
     
     
     
     
    | 5:27 AM
